conclusion: Determine the height \( h_a \) from which the small ball \( a \) is released so that it can just fly out from point \( D \).
Use energy conservation and dynamics principles to find the solution.
The small ball \( a \) is released from rest at height \( h_a \) on the inclined plane \( PA \).
Potential energy at height \( h_a \) is converted into kinetic energy as the ball slides down the incline.
Potential Energy at \( P \): \( U_P = mgh_a \).
Kinetic Energy at \( A \): \( K_A =  rac{1}{2}mv_A^2 = mgh_a \).
The ball moves horizontally from \( A \) to \( B \) with the same speed as at \( A \).
The ball enters the semicircular track at \( B \) and moves towards \( D \).
At point \( D \), the ball must have just enough speed to fly off, meaning the normal force at \( D \) is zero.
Condition for Flying Off at \( D \): \(  rac{mv_D^2}{R} = mg \).
Energy Conservation from \( B \) to \( D \): \(  rac{1}{2}mv_B^2 =  rac{1}{2}mv_D^2 + mg(2R) + qE(2R) \).
Since \( v_B = v_A \), \( mgh_a =  rac{1}{2}mgR + mg(2R) + qE(2R) \).
Assuming the ball is neutral (no charge), the electric field does not do any work: \( mgh_a =  rac{1}{2}mgR + mg(2R) \).
